DOI: 10.1016/S1872-2067(11)60403-8 ARTICLE (1S,2S)-Diphenylethylenediamine Modified Ir/SiO 2 Catalyst for Asymmetric Hydrogenation of Acetophenone and Its Derivatives YANG Chaofen 1 , YANG Jun 1 , SUN Xiaodong 1 , ZHU Yanqin 1 , WANG Qi 1 , CHEN Hua 2, * 1 Research Center for Analysis and Measurement, Kunming University of Science and Technology, Kunming 650093, Yunnan, China 2 Key Laboratory of Green Chemistry and Technology, Ministry of Education, Institute of Homogeneous Catalysis, College of Chemistry, Si- chuan University, Chengdu 610064, Sichuan, China Abstract: An efficient and highly dispersed 5%Ir/SiO 2 catalyst for the asymmetric hydrogenation of acetophenone and its derivatives were prepared under basic conditions without the use of any stabilizer. The effects of different reaction parameters, namely, catalyst preparation, base used, chiral modifier, and concentration of (1S,2S)-diphenylethylenediamine ((1S,2S)-DPEN), were evaluated. Under optimum con- ditions with 5%Ir/SiO 2 modified by (1S,2S)-DPEN, a high ee value of 70.0% was obtained for the asymmetric hydrogenation of aceto- phenone. It is noteworthy that this highest ee value was obtained with a supported metal catalyst without any stabilizer. The catalyst preparation is simple and there was no loss of enantioselectivity when the catalyst was reused several times. Key words: iridium; acetophenone; heterogeneous asymmetric hydrogenation; (1S,2S)-diphenylethylenediamine; enantioselectivity Catalytic hydrogenation is widely used in both research and industry [1â€“3] because hydrogen is clean and easily available at very low cost. Heterogeneous asymmetric hydrogenation has operational and economical advantages such as facilitating the separation of the catalyst from the reaction medium, and easy recovery and reuse of the expensive and toxic chiral com- pounds [4]. Therefore, the development of heterogeneous chiral catalysts has attracted much attention in recent years [5â€“9]. However, due to the high substrate specificity of these catalysts and the difficulties in understanding and designing the reactions, there have been just three established systems reported so far [10]. Numerous efforts have been made for the chiral modification of supported metal catalysts for asymmet- ric hydrogenation. One approach is by simply adding a chiral modifier to the reaction mixture or depositing it onto the catalyst surface in a pretreatment step before the reaction. Vargas et al. [11,12] successfully used cinchona modified Pt/Al 2 O 3 in the asymmetric hydrogenation of activated aro- matic ketones. However, there are few successful heteroge- neous catalyst examples for the asymmetric hydrogenation of simple aromatic ketones and their derivatives, which is one of the most fundamental subject in modern synthetic chemistry [13â€“16]. Recently, our group used (1S,2S)-diphenylethyl- enediamine ((1S,2S)-DPEN) modified Ir/HAP(hydroxyapatite) in the asymmetric hydrogenation of acetophenone and its de- rivatives, and obtained 63.7% ee value for (R)-phenylethanol [17]. Marzialetti et al. [18] have reported a cinchonidine modified Ir/SiO 2 catalyst for the asymmetric hydrogenation of acetophenone that gave 60.2% ee value for (R)-phenylethanol but they had to use a larger amount of cinchonidine and cata- lyst. Although the enantioselectivity for the hydrogenation of acetophenone was improved by using supported ruthenium as catalyst, air and moisture sensitive phosphine must be added as a stabilizer to have high activity and enantioselectivity [19â€“23]. There were much trouble and drawbacks due to the instability of phosphine, e.g., the inconvenience of preventing the oxygenation of phosphine, the decline of enantioselectivity and difficult recycle of the catalyst. We have previous reported a cinchonidine and L-proline stabilized Ir for the hydrogenation of acetophenoen that gave good enantioselectivity [24,25]. The heterogeneous asymmetric hydrogenation of simple aromatic YANG Chaofen et al. / Chinese Journal of Catalysis, 2012, 33: 1154â€“1160 ketones catalyzed by supported metal catalysts modified by chiral reagents is a highly challenging task, esp. the finding of a catalyst that does not need a stabilizer. In this paper, we de- scribe the asymmetric hydrogenation of acetophenone and its derivatives by (1S,2S)-DPEN modified Ir/SiO 2 as catalyst. Acetophenone and its derivatives were hydrogenated with good enantioselectivity. 1 Experiment 1.1 Preparation of catalyst H 2 IrCl 6 Â·6H 2 O (0.14 g) and an excess of LiOH were dis- solved in a mixture of EtOH and distilled water (V(EtOH)/V(H 2 O) = 10/1), to which SiO 2 (1 g) was added. After stirring for 1 h at room temperature in the autoclave, hydrogen was introduced and pressurized to 3.0 MPa and the reaction mixture was stirred at 373 K for another 5 h. After the mixture was cooled to room temperature, the solid was filtered and washed with ethanol. Then, the solid was dried under vacuum at 323 K for 1 h to give the Ir/SiO 2 catalyst. The iridium content of all catalysts was 5 wt%, which was determined by inductively coupled plasma (ICP) analysis. 1.2 Asymmetric hydrogenation of acetophenone The hydrogenation was performed in a 60 ml stainless autoclave with a magnetic stirrer. A typical procedure for the asymmetric hydrogenation of acetophenone is as follows. The catalyst, chiral modifier (Acros, >98%), base, MeOH, and acetophenone (Acros, >99%) were added to the autoclave, followed by purging with hydrogen three times. Hydrogen was introduced to the desired pressure. The mixture was stirred at the reaction temperature for a given time. After the reaction, the pressure was released, and the products were separated and sent for analysis by a GC with a FID detector and a È•-DEXTM120 capillary column (30 m Ã— 0.25 mm, 0.25 Pm film). The enantiomeric excess (ee value) was calculated from the equation: ee = (S â€“ R)/(S + R). 1.3 Characterization of catalyst The morphology of catalyst was examined with a transmis- sion electron microscope (TEM, JEM-1200) at an accelerating voltage of 100 kV. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was performed on a Kratos XAM800 in the constant pass energy mode and with non-monochromatic Mg K Ä® X-ray ra- diation (hÈž = 1253.6 eV). 2 Results and discussion 2.1 Influence of the base used and catalyst characterization Since H 2 IrCl 6 is acidic, the effect of the base used in the catalyst preparation to get a high performance catalyst was studied. As shown in Table 1, the catalysts prepared in the presence of a base were distinctly superior to that prepared with no base. The catalyst prepared in the presence of LiOH showed the best activity and enantioselectivity for the asymmetric hydrogenation of acetophenone. In addition, the weak bases Li 2 CO 3 and N(Et) 3 added in the preparation of catalyst were more helpful than the strong bases NaOH and KOH. It was determined by ICP analysis that there was no alkali metal cation in the catalyst. Thus the basicity, rather than the alkali metal cation, was the key factor that determined the perform- ance of the catalyst. Figures 1(a) and (b) are the TEM images of the catalyst prepared in the presence of LiOH and in the absence of a base, respectively. Comparing Fig. 1(a) with Fig. 1(b), it can be seen that the Ir particles were well dispersed on SiO 2 in the preparation with the presence of LiOH, and the Table 1 Effect of different bases on the catalyst performance Base n(base):n(Ir) Conversion (%) ee (%) Configuration No 0 5.0 30.0 R LiOH 18:1 99.4 62.4 R Li 2 CO 3 18:1 43.5 55.2 R NaOH 9:1 67.0 50.4 R KOH 9:1 38.4 47.9 R N(Et) 3 25:1 73.9 59.1 R Reaction conditions: n(acetophenone):n(Ir) = 163:1, acetophenone 0.85 mmol, LiOH 0.35 mol/L, (1S,2S)-DPEN 5.2 Ã— 10 â€“3 mol/L, MeOH 2 ml, p(H 2 ) = 2.0 MPa, 323 K, 3 h. (a) (b) Fig. 1. TEM image of 5%Ir/SiO 2 . (a) 5%Ir/SiO 2 prepared in the pres- ence of LiOH; (b) 5%Ir/SiO 2 prepared in the absence of a base. YANG Chaofen et al. / Chinese Journal of Catalysis, 2012, 33: 1154â€“1160 particle size of Ir was about 2 nm. A high dispersion and nanoparticles result in a large Ir surface area and good catalytic performance [26]. The XPS analysis showed that the Ir 0 signal (4f 7/2 binding energies at 60.7 eV) from 5%Ir/SiO 2 prepared with the pres- ence of LiOH (Fig. 2(a)) was larger than that from the catalyst prepared without any base (Fig. 2(b)). This indicated that the metal prepared under basic condition can be reduced more easily. Furthermore, the base was also very important in the asymmetric hydrogenation reaction. As shown in Table 2, the use of LiOH gave the best enantioselectivity among the bases used. When a weak organic base N(Et) 3 was added to the cata- lytic system, the conversion and ee value were only 59.6% and 41.4%, respectively. In the presence of strong inorganic bases such as NaOH or KOH, the conversion was improved but with a loss in the ee value. Interestingly, the enantioselectivity in the presence of the weaker inorganic base Li 2 CO 3 was inferior to that with LiOH. These observations suggest that it was not only the basicity that affected reaction activity and enantioselectiv- ity, but the alkali metal cation also played an important role in the reaction enantioselectivity. This is in agreement with pre- vious results [27â€“30] that a strong base can attack the proton on the nitrogen atom of (1S,2S)-DPEN and form a negative ni- trogen atom in (1S,2S)-DPEN that was coordinated to iridium. The negative nitrogen atom induced the heterolytic splitting of the dihydrogen coordinated to the metal center. In addition, the alkali metal cation was S-bonded to the aryl groups in (1S,2S)-DPEN, thus, the alkali metal cation radius has to suitable for the specific bonding site [31]. In our system, Li + was the most suitable alkali metal cation, which was why LiOH and Li 2 CO 3 gave better ee values with Ir as the active metal. 2.2 Influence of chiral modifier The effect of different modifiers on the asymmetric hydro- genation of acetophenone was examined. The results are summarized in Table 3. (1S,2S)-DPEN was the best, with which the conversion of acetophenone and enantioselectivity to (R)-phenyl ethanol were increased to 99.4% and 62.4%, respectively. The chiral diamines containing a bulkier group were unfavorable for the reaction. For example, in the pres- ence of (1S,2S)-TsDPEN ((1S,2S)-N-p-methylphenyl-sulfonyl- 1,2-diphenyl-1,2-ethanediamine) [32] or (1R,2R)-DMTFM- DPEN ((1R,2R)-(+)-N,N-dimethyl-1,2-bis[3-(trifluoro- methyl)phenyl-1,2-ethanediamine]), both conversion and ee value were lower than those with (1S,2S)-DPEN. In addition, (1R,2R)-DACH ((1R,2R)-(â€“)-1,2-diaminocyclohexane) with the rigid cyclohexyl structure gave low conversion and ee value. Compared with chiral diamines, when chiral modifiers with only an amino or no amino (i.e. cinchonidine, L-proline, and L-tartaric acid) were used, the reaction activity and enan- tioselectivity were clearly decreased. The data indicate that the 1,2-diamine structure was important for high activity and (a) 70 68 66 64 62 60 58 56 I n t e n s i t y Bonding energy (eV) (b) I n t e n s i t y Fig. 2. XPS profile for 5%Ir/SiO 2 . (a) 5%Ir/SiO 2 prepared in the pres- ence of LiOH; (b) 5%Ir/SiO 2 prepared in the absence of a base. Table 2 Effect of base on the asymmetric hydrogenation of acetophe- none Base Concentration (mol/L) Conversion (%) ee (%) Configuration no 0.00 47.3 39.1 R LiOH 0.35 99.4 62.4 R Li 2 CO 3 0.18 70.7 59.6 R NaOH 0.15 98.9 57.3 R KOH 0.15 98.4 55.9 R N(Et) 3 0.35 59.6 41.4 R Reaction conditions were the same as those in Table 1 except base. Table 3 Effect of chiral modifier on the asymmetric hydrogenation of acetophenone Modifier n(modifier): n(Ir) Conversion (%) ee (%) Configuration (1S,2S)-DPEN 2:1 99.4 62.4 R (1R,2R)-DPEN 2:1 100 56.8 S (1R,2R)- DMTFM-DPEN 2:1 56.3 54.5 S (1R,2R)-DACH 2:1 57.5 52.7 S (1S,2S)-TsDPEN 2:1 51.2 40.4 R Cinchonidine 2:1 42.8 36.8 R L-proline 15:1 51.7 22.2 R L-tartaric acid 10:1 28.1 6.8 R Reaction conditions were the same as those in Table 1 except chiral modifier. YANG Chaofen et al. / Chinese Journal of Catalysis, 2012, 33: 1154â€“1160 enantioselectivity. This may be because the coordination abil- ity of the nitrogen atom was stronger than that of the oxygen atom [33] so that the chelating ring formed by 1,2-diamine with iridium was more stable. This would explain why the activity and enantioselectivity were very poor even in the presence of a large amount of L-tartaric acid. To further study the effect of the modifier on the asymmet- ric hydrogenation of acetophenone, the effect of (1S,2S)-DPEN concentration was investigated (Table 4). In the absence of (1S,2S)-DPEN, the reaction almost did not proceed. When the (1S,2S)-DPEN concentration was just 1.3 Ã— 10 â€“3 mol/L, corresponding to a (1S,2S)-DPEN/Ir molar ratio of 0.5, 60.0% ee value was achieved with 64.1% conversion. On further increasing the (1S,2S)-DPEN concentration from 2.6 Ã— 10 â€“3 to 9.1 Ã— 10 â€“3 mol/L (the molar ratio of (1S,2S)- DPEN/Ir was increased from 1:1 to 4:1), the conversion was increased from 64.1% to 100% while ee value was slightly increased. This demonstrated that the active species was formed through the coordination of (1S,2S)-DPEN to Ir on the surface of the support, and this was a key factor for high con- version and ee value. Our result is in good agreement with the catalysis with PPh 3 and diamine modified Ru/È–-Al 3 O 2 [34]. With a decreased (1S,2S)-DPEN concentration, only few metal centers were coordinated with (1S,2S)-DPEN on the support surface, and so the catalytic activity was poor. In this system, the active species formed on the support surface was the most when the (1S,2S)-DPEN concentration was 2.6 Ã— 10 â€“3 mol/L, since further increasing the (1S,2S)-DPEN concentra- tion did not improve the activity. In the hydrogenation of ace- tophenone catalyzed by cinchonidine modified Pt/È–-Al 3 O 2 , a similar result was observed [35]. 2.3 Influence of hydrogen pressure The influence of hydrogen pressure on reaction activity and enantioselectivity is shown in Fig. 3. At 2.0 MPa pressure, the conversion and enantioselectivity were 99.4% and 62.4%, respectively. The conversion and ee value increased initially with the increase of hydrogen pressure, and then they de- creased gradually for pressure above 2.0 MPa. The effect of hydrogen pressure on the hydrogenation reaction demonstrated that competitive adsorption between the substrates (H 2 and acetophenone) and (1S,2S)-DPEN on the Ir surface exist. A low pressure resulted in low hydrogen concentration at the Ir center, and was unfavorable for activity and enantioselectivity [36]. When the pressure was moderately increased, the Ir cen- ters were completely occupied by H 2 and (1S,2S)-DPEN, and so excellent catalytic activity and selectivity were obtained. However, as the pressure was further increased, too much H 2 adsorbed on the catalyst surface led to the desorption of (1S,2S)-DPEN and resulted in low conversion and ee value. 2.4 Influence of temperature Figure 4 shows the effect of temperature on the asymmetric hydrogenation of acetophenone. With the increase of tem- perature from 283 to 333 K, the conversion increased dra- matically from 50% to 100%. The best ee value was 70.0% obtained at 293 K. With further increasing or lowering of the reaction temperature, the enantioselectivity decreased. A similar result was also reported in the literature [19,37,38]. It may be that H 2 was not efficiently activated on the Ir surface Table 4 Effect of (1S,2S)-DPEN concentration on the asymmetric hydrogenation of acetophenone c((1S,2S)-DPEN) (10 â€“3 mol/L) n((1S,2S)-DPEN): n(Ir) Conversion (%) ee (%) Configuration 0.0 0 2.9 0 â€” 1.3 0.5:1 64.1 60.0 R 2.6 1:1 98.1 61.6 R 5.2 2:1 99.4 62.4 R 7.8 3:1 99.8 62.6 R 9.1 4:1 100 63.4 R Reaction conditions were the same as those in Table 1 except (1S,2S)-DPEN concentration. 0.0 0.5 1.0 1.5 2.0 2.5 3.0 3.5 4.0 4.5 40 50 60 70 80 90 100 Conversion ee Pressure (MPa) C o n v e r s i o n ( % ) 45 50 55 60 65 e e ( % ) Fig. 3. Effect of pressure on the asymmetric hydrogenation of aceto- phenone. Reaction conditions were the same as those in Table 1 except for the H 2 pressure. 280 290 300 310 320 330 30 40 50 60 70 80 90 100 Conversion ee Temperature (K) C o n v e r s i o n ( % ) 58 60 62 64 66 68 70 e e ( % ) Fig. 4. Effect of temperature on the asymmetric hydrogenation of ace- tophenone. Reaction conditions were the same as those in Table 1 except the temperature. YANG Chaofen et al. / Chinese Journal of Catalysis, 2012, 33: 1154â€“1160 at a low temperature, which diminished the catalytic activity and enantioselectivity. However, the energy difference be- tween the transition states of the two enantiomers would be- come smaller with increasing temperature, resulting in de- creased ee value. 2.5 Asymmetric hydrogenation of acetophenone and its derivatives Acetophenone and its derivatives were hydrogenated with the (1S,2S)-DPEN modified 5%Ir/SiO 2 catalyst. The results are summarized in Table 5. The catalyst gave high enantioselec- tivities except with 2Æ�-methoxyacetophenone. In particular, 84.0% ee value was obtained for the asymmetric hydrogenation of 2Æ�-(trifluoromethyl)acetophenone. Obviously, the electronic and steric effects markedly affect the reaction activity and enantioselectivity. 2.6 Recycling of the catalyst To explore the stability of the catalyst, recycling of the catalyst was investigated. After the first run, the reaction mixture was centrifuged, and the catalyst was separated from the liquid mixture by centrifugation. The catalyst was washed three times with MeOH and then reintroduced into the reactor with MeOH and fresh acetophenone, (1S,2S)-DPEN and LiOH for the recycle run. The catalyst could be reused six times without significant loss of enantioselectivity. However, (1S,2S)-DPEN must be added in each run because it was solu- ble in the organic solution and remained in the solution after reaction. To avoid this, we added (1S,2S)-DPEN in the process of catalyst preparation to get the 5%Ir-(1S,2S)-DPEN/SiO 2 catalyst, which exhibited good stability in the recycling with- out (1S,2S)-DPEN being added. As shown in Fig. 5, the 5%Ir-(1S,2S)-DPEN/SiO 2 catalyst could be reused four times and the ee values was maintained in the range from 55.8% to 57.6%. These ee values were lower than that obtained with (1S,2S)-DPEN added in situ. The activity decrease was probably due to the loss of 5%Ir-(1S,2S)-DPEN/SiO 2 in the separation process. The leaching of Ir from 5%Ir/SiO 2 into the solution was determined by ICP, but only 0.1% Ir was de- tected in the liquid phase after the first hydrogenation of ace- tophenone. 2.7 Comparison with the other heterogeneous catalyst systems In the literature, the enantioselectivity in the hydrogenation of acetophenone with supported transition metal catalysts modified with chiral modifiers is still low (Table 6). For ex- ample, an ee of 28.8% was obtained over a S-proline modified Pd/SBA-15 catalyst [16]. Although ee value could be increased to 60.2% over cinchonidine modified Ir/SiO 2 catalyst, this required a higher cinchonidine concentration [18]. Very re- cently, Baiker et al. [13] reported cinchonidine modiÂ¿ed Pt/Al 2 O 3 -SiO 2 for the asymmetric hydrogenation of aceto- Table 5 Asymmetric hydrogenation of acetophenone and its derivatives Substrate Conversion (%) ee (%) Configuration Acetophenone 75.6 70.0 R Propioacetophenone 85.6 67.4 R Isobutyacetophenone a 74.2 70.9 R 2Æ�-Fluoroacetophenone 66.8 64.6 R 2Æ�-Cloroacetophenone 70.8 70.9 R 2Æ�-Bromoacetophenone 74.7 70.0 R 2Æ�-(Trifluoromethyl)acetophenone a 55.0 84.0 R 2Æ�-Methoxyacetophenone a 77.1 40.9 R Reaction conditions were the same as those in Table 1 except that the temperature was 293 K. a Reaction time was 12 h. 1234 0 20 40 60 80 100 ( % ) Run Conversion ee Fig. 5. Table 6 Comparison of the entioselectivity of acetophenone hydro- genation with heterogeneous catalysts modified by chiral reagents Modifier and catalyst ee (%) Reference S-proline-modiÂ¿ed Pd/C a 22.5 [14] S-proline-modiÂ¿ed Pd/SBA-15 b 28.8 [16] Cinchona-modiÂ¿ed Pt/C c 20 [15] Cinchonidine-modiÂ¿ed Pt/Al 2 O 3 -SiO 2 d 63 [13] Cinchonidine-modiÂ¿ed Pt/Al 2 O 3 d 33 [13] Cinchonidine-modified Ir/SiO 2 e 60.2 [18] (1S,2S)-DPEN-modified Ir/HAP f 63.7 [17] (1S,2S)-DPEN-modified Ir/SiO 2 70.0 present work Reaction conditions: a 400 mg Pd/C, S-proline 5.25 g, 0.05 mol aceto- phenone, MeOH as solvent, 0.5 MPa, 298 K, 1.2 h; b 50 mg Pd/SBA-15, S-proline 500 mg, 0.86 mmol acetophenone, 3.0 MPa, 288 K, 10 min; c 80 mg Pt/C,40 mg cinchonidine, 0.7 mmol acetophenone, isooctane and H 2 O as solvent, 0.1 MPa, 298 K, 5 h; d 42 mg Pt/Al 2 O 3 -SiO 2 (Pt/Al 2 O 3 ), 8 mg cinchonidine, 0.92 mmol acetophenone, toluene as solvent, 9.0 MPa, 293 K, 4 h; e 100 mg Ir/SiO 2 , 5.0 g cinchonidine, 0.58 mol acetophenone, cyclohexane as solvent, 4.0 MPa, 298 K, 6 h; f 20 mg Ir/HAP, 4.0 mg (1S,2S)-DPEN, 0.85 mmol acetophenone, MeOH as solvent, 3.0 MPa, 303 K, 3 h. YANG Chaofen et al. / Chinese Journal of Catalysis, 2012, 33: 1154â€“1160 pheone with which 63% and 33% ee values were obtained, but with only 2% and 55% conversions, respectively [13]. In our present work with the (1S,2S)-DPEN modified 5%Ir/SiO 2 catalyst, an excellent ee value of 70.0% was obtained. This is a higher enantioselectivity than any value reported up to now for acetophenone hydrogenation catalyzed by a supported metal catalyst modified by a chiral reagent. 3 Conclusions A (1S,2S)-DPEN modified Ir/SiO 2 catalyst showed excellent catalytic activity and enantioselectivity for the asymmetric hydrogenation of acetophenone and its derivatives. The preparation of the catalyst is simple and the catalyst can be reused several times without significant loss of enantioselec- tivity. The use of a suitable alkali is the key factor for preparing a highly efficient catalyst. References 1 Herrmann W A, Cornils B. Acta Phys-Chim Sin, 2009, 25: 2039 18 Marzialetti T, Oportus M, Ruiz D, Fierro CHNJC 60403 S1872-2067(11)60403-8 10.1016/S1872-2067(11)60403-8 Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, the Chinese Academy of Sciences ARTICLE (1S,2S)-Diphenylethylenediamine Modified Ir/SiO2 Catalyst for Asymmetric Hydrogenation of Acetophenone and Its Derivatives Chaofen YANG a Jun YANG a Xiaodong SUN a Yanqin ZHU a Qi WANG a Hua CHEN b * a Research Center for Analysis and Measurement, Kunming University of Science and Technology, Kunming 650093, Yunnan, China b Key Laboratory of Green Chemistry and Technology, Ministry of Education, Institute of Homogeneous Catalysis, College of Chemistry, Sichuan University, Chengdu 610064, Sichuan, China * Corresponding author. Tel/Fax: +86-28-85412904 An efficient and highly dispersed 5%Ir/SiO2 catalyst for the asymmetric hydrogenation of acetophenone and its derivatives were prepared under basic conditions without the use of any stabilizer. The effects of different reaction parameters, namely, catalyst preparation, base used, chiral modifier, and concentration of (1S,2S)-diphenylethylenediamine ((1S,2S)-DPEN), were evaluated. Under optimum conditions with 5%Ir/SiO2 modified by (1S,2S)-DPEN, a high ee value of 70.0% was obtained for the asymmetric hydrogenation of acetophenone. It is noteworthy that this highest ee value was obtained with a supported metal catalyst without any stabilizer. The catalyst preparation is simple and there was no loss of enantioselectivity when the catalyst was reused several times. 摘要 不添加任何稳定剂, 在碱性条件下制备了 5%Ir/SiO2 催化剂, 并用于催化苯乙酮的不对称加氢反应中, 详细考察了碱和手性修饰剂种类、氢气压力、反应温度、(1S,2S)-1,2-二苯基乙二胺 ((1S,2S)-DPEN) 浓度对反应的影响. 在优化反应条件下, 5%Ir/SiO2 催化剂表现出较好的反应活性和对映选择性. 其中, 苯乙酮不对称加氢反应的对映选择性达 70%. 该催化剂不需要任何稳定剂, 制备方法简单, 催化性能稳定, 通过简单的离心分离即可循环使用. Graphical abstract 5%Ir/SiO2 prepared under basic conditions exhibited good catalytic performance in the asymmetric hydrogenation of acetophenone and its derivatives. coredata.dc:description: An efficient and highly dispersed 5%Ir/SiO2 catalyst for the asymmetric hydrogenation of acetophenone and its derivatives were prepared under basic conditions without the use of any stabilizer. The effects of different reaction parameters, namely, catalyst preparation, base used, chiral modifier, and concentration of (1S,2S)-diphenylethylenediamine ((1S,2S)-DPEN), were evaluated. Under optimum conditions with 5%Ir/SiO2 modified by (1S,2S)-DPEN, a high ee value of 70.0% was obtained for the asymmetric hydrogenation of acetophenone. It is noteworthy that this highest ee value was obtained with a supported metal catalyst without any stabilizer. The catalyst preparation is simple and there was no loss of enantioselectivity when the catalyst was reused several times.
